title: Suggestions for alternatives to Didot?
content:
Hi Typophiles,

I am designing a book about fashion, and I'm trying to avoid using the standard Didot.I'm sure you all have some ideas? Thank you so much for your help.

Janet
author: Plaidjaney

comments.content:
You can certainly start here: [http://www.fontshop.com/fontlist/subclasses/serif\_modern/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150219021524/http:/www.fontshop.com/fontlist/subclasses/serif_modern/)

H&FJ has a great cut of [Didot](http://web.archive.org/web/20150219021524/http:/www.typography.com/fonts/font_overview.php?productLineID=100004).

(I first interpreted "standard Didot" as the cut the comes bundled with your computer or software. Now, I think you may have meant not an alternative cut, but an alternative style altogether. Sorry for the misunderstanding!)

Hi,

Thanks for the response. I don't want an alternative style altogether, but just something similar with the thicks and thins. Your link has a few to start with so you are helpful!

Hi,

Thanks for the response. I don't want an alternative style altogether, but just something similiar with the thicks and thins. Your link has a few to start with so you are helpful!

Depending on how many headlines there is, how about commisioning a calligrapher or a lettering artist? I remember Acne Magazine did, for the script they paired with Didot. It worked great.

Also, don’t write of sans serifs! There is a custom face called Fashion Thin that is very interesting. Related: [Finura](http://web.archive.org/web/20150219021524/http:/www.dstype.com/index.php?id=61)

Edit: Never mind:) Spent to much time writing this post

Hi FF,

They are giving me four days to design a 4-color book :o) No time for anything. I love your suggestions!

Headlines or body text?  
Some suggestions here:  
 [http://typophile.com/node/42830](http://web.archive.org/web/20150219021524/http:/typophile.com/node/42830 "http://typophile.com/node/42830")  
 [http://typophile.com/node/62447](http://web.archive.org/web/20150219021524/http:/typophile.com/node/62447 "http://typophile.com/node/62447")

Try out Scotch Modern from [Shinntype](http://web.archive.org/web/20150219021524/http:/shinntype.com/). Optical sizes, a companion sans, and instead of using a high-end Didot you’re using a killer modern design that people don’t just recognize.

Thank you so much riccad0!

Thanks James-I will try Scotch Modern. I actually do need a sans, too!
I’ve got a sans in the fashion segment on the steps. If you only need AZ+numerals it might be of interest to you.
Believe it or not, they are going with Didot and Gotham. I like these two, but wanted to go a little off the norm. What is the name of your sans?

I am about to release a type family designed to offer a good alternative to Didot and Bodoni. If you mail me to [info@re-type.com](mailto:info@re-type.com) I will be happy to send you some examples.

Cheers.

Ramiro.

How about the less commonplace didone fonts [Yves Peters suggests](http://web.archive.org/web/20150219021524/http:/fontfeed.com/archives/screenfonts-august-2009/) in his ScreenFonts article: [FF Holmen](http://web.archive.org/web/20150219021524/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/fontfont/ff_holmen_ot/) or [FF Danubia](http://web.archive.org/web/20150219021524/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/fontfont/ff_danubia/)?

You could also have a little fun with Peter Biľak’s History (combining History 01 and History 03, which could give you a nice “Didot Sans”).  
 [http://www.typotheque.com/fonts/history](http://web.archive.org/web/20150219021524/http:/www.typotheque.com/fonts/history "http://www.typotheque.com/fonts/history")
